  <div id="readme" class="blob instapaper_body">
    <article class="markdown-body entry-content" itemprop="mainContentOfPage"><table data-table-type="yaml-metadata">
  <thead>
  <tr>
  <th>title</th>

  <th>output</th>
  </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
  <tr>
  <td><div>Practical Machine Learning: Course Project Writeup</div></td>

  <td><div>html_document</div></td>
  </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

<h3><a id="user-content-question" class="anchor" href="#question" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Question</h3>

<p>Using devices such as Jawbone Up, Nike FuelBand, and Fitbit it is now possible to collect a large amount of data about personal activity relatively inexpensively. One thing that people regularly do is quantify how much of a particular activity they do, but they rarely quantify how well they do it. </p>

<p>In this project, your goal will be to use data from accelerometers on the belt, forearm, arm, and dumbell of 6 participants. They were asked to perform barbell lifts correctly and incorrectly in 5 different ways. More information is available from the website here: <a href="http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har">http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har</a>.  </p>

<h3><a id="user-content-input-data" class="anchor" href="#input-data" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Input Data</h3>

<p>First load both the Training and Testing data provided. The data for this project come from this source: <a href="http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har">http://groupware.les.inf.puc-rio.br/har</a>. </p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">RCurl</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> read.csv(<span class="pl-v">text</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> getURL(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-training.csv<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>))
<span class="pl-smi">TestingData</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> read.csv(<span class="pl-v">text</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> getURL(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/predmachlearn/pml-testing.csv<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>))

<span class="pl-c">#Dimension of training data</span>
dim(<span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>)</pre></div>

<h3><a id="user-content-features" class="anchor" href="#features" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Features</h3>

<p><strong>Data Preprocessing</strong><br>
We perform several data preprocessing steps necessary to improve our analysis. The processes below aims to remove predictors they would not contribute well to the prediction.  </p>

<p><strong>Remove highly correlated predictors (in our case the correlation value is selected to be &gt;90%)</strong></p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">caret</span>)
<span class="pl-c">#Only calculate correlation for predictors that are numeric</span>
<span class="pl-smi">correlation</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> cor(na.omit(<span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>[sapply(<span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>, <span class="pl-smi">is.numeric</span>)]))

<span class="pl-v">remove</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> findCorrelation(<span class="pl-smi">correlation</span>, <span class="pl-v">cutoff</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> .<span class="pl-c1">90</span>, <span class="pl-v">verbose</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>)
<span class="pl-v">TrainingData</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>[,<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-smi">remove</span>]

<span class="pl-c">#Dimension of training data adter removing correlated predictors</span>
dim(<span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>)</pre></div>

<p><strong>Remove predictors with too many NA values.</strong></p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">containsNA</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> sapply(<span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>, <span class="pl-k">function</span> (<span class="pl-smi">x</span>) any(is.na(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>) <span class="pl-k">|</span> <span class="pl-smi">x</span> <span class="pl-k">==</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span><span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>))
<span class="pl-c">#Also include variables like "kurtosis_roll_belt, skewness_roll_belt, skewness_yaw_arm etc" that contains mostly empty values</span>
<span class="pl-smi">isPredictor</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-k">!</span><span class="pl-smi">containsNA</span> <span class="pl-k">&amp;</span> grepl(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>belt|forearm|[^(fore)]arm|dumbbell<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, names(<span class="pl-smi">containsNA</span>))
<span class="pl-smi">predCandidates</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> names(<span class="pl-smi">containsNA</span>)[<span class="pl-smi">isPredictor</span>]
<span class="pl-c">#Include the "classe" predictor variable</span>
<span class="pl-smi">varToInclude</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>classe<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-smi">predCandidates</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>[, <span class="pl-smi">varToInclude</span>]

<span class="pl-c">#Dimension of training data</span>
dim(<span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>)</pre></div>

<p><strong>Remove predictors that have extremely low variance using the nearZeroVar() function.</strong></p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">zeroVar</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> nearZeroVar(<span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>[sapply(<span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>, <span class="pl-smi">is.numeric</span>)], <span class="pl-v">saveMetrics</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">TRUE</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>[,<span class="pl-smi">zeroVar</span>[, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>nzv<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>]<span class="pl-k">==</span><span class="pl-c1">0</span>]

<span class="pl-c">#Dimension of training data</span>
dim(<span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>)</pre></div>

<p><strong>Split data to 60% training and 40% testing for cross validation.</strong></p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">inTrain</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> createDataPartition(<span class="pl-v">y</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">classe</span>, <span class="pl-v">p</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">0.6</span>, <span class="pl-v">list</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">TrainingSplit</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>[<span class="pl-smi">inTrain</span>,]
<span class="pl-smi">TestingSplit</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">TrainingData</span>[<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-smi">inTrain</span>,]

<span class="pl-c">#Dimension of training and testing data after partitioning</span>
dim(<span class="pl-smi">TrainingSplit</span>)
dim(<span class="pl-smi">TestingSplit</span>)</pre></div>

<h3><a id="user-content-algorithm" class="anchor" href="#algorithm" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Algorithm</h3>

<p>Here we make use of 2 machine learning algorithms to build our models. The first is rpart: Recursive Partitioning and Regression Trees, and the second is the random forest algorithm. The out of sample error will be estimated using the 40% training sample. <strong>We expect a small out of sample error, estimated to be less than 3%.</strong>  </p>

<p><strong>rpart: Recursive Partitioning and Regression Trees</strong></p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">rpart</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">ModelRPart</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> train(<span class="pl-smi">classe</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> .,<span class="pl-v">method</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>rpart<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,<span class="pl-v">data</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">TrainingSplit</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">ModelRPart</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">finalModel</span></pre></div>

<p><strong>Random forest</strong></p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">randomForest</span>)
set.seed(<span class="pl-c1">52368</span>)

<span class="pl-smi">ModelRandomForest</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> randomForest(<span class="pl-smi">classe</span><span class="pl-k">~</span>.,<span class="pl-v">data</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">TrainingSplit</span>,<span class="pl-v">ntree</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">200</span>, <span class="pl-v">importance</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">TRUE</span>)</pre></div>

<p><strong>Out-of Sample Accuracy</strong><br>
Our Random Forest model shows OOB estimate of error rate: 1.43% for the training data. <strong>The predicted out-of sample accuracy on the test data has an estimated error rate is less than 1%.</strong></p>

<h3><a id="user-content-evaluation-cross-validation" class="anchor" href="#evaluation-cross-validation" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Evaluation (Cross-Validation)</h3>

<p><strong>rPart</strong>
We calculate the error rate of our rpart predictor.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">tree.pred</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">ModelRPart</span>,<span class="pl-smi">TestingSplit</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">predMatrix</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> with(<span class="pl-smi">TestingSplit</span>,table(<span class="pl-smi">tree.pred</span>,<span class="pl-smi">classe</span>))
sum(diag(<span class="pl-smi">predMatrix</span>))<span class="pl-k">/</span>sum(as.vector(<span class="pl-smi">predMatrix</span>)) <span class="pl-c"># error rate</span></pre></div>

<p>We obtain a very poor model with an estimated error rate of 0.49.</p>

<p><strong>Random forest</strong>
We calculate the error rate of our random forest predictor.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">rf.pred</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> predict(<span class="pl-smi">ModelRandomForest</span>,<span class="pl-smi">TestingSplit</span>,<span class="pl-v">type</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>class<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
<span class="pl-smi">predictor</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> with(<span class="pl-smi">TestingSplit</span>,table(<span class="pl-smi">rf.pred</span>,<span class="pl-smi">classe</span>))
sum(diag(<span class="pl-smi">predictor</span>))<span class="pl-k">/</span>sum(as.vector(<span class="pl-smi">predictor</span>)) <span class="pl-c"># error rate</span></pre></div>

<p>We obtain a very accurate estimated error rate of 0.9866, which will be selected to be our final model.  </p>

<h3><a id="user-content-test-data-submission" class="anchor" href="#test-data-submission" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Test Data Submission</h3>

<p>Make use of the random forest algorithm that was built earlier to predict the results of TestingData. Outputting the results using the provided pml_write_files function.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-v">pml_write_files</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">function</span>(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>){
  <span class="pl-v">n</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> length(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>)
  <span class="pl-k">for</span>(<span class="pl-smi">i</span> <span class="pl-k">in</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span><span class="pl-k">:</span><span class="pl-smi">n</span>){
    <span class="pl-v">filename</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> paste0(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>problem_id_<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,<span class="pl-smi">i</span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>.txt<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)
    write.table(<span class="pl-smi">x</span>[<span class="pl-smi">i</span>],<span class="pl-v">file</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-smi">filename</span>,<span class="pl-v">quote</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>,<span class="pl-v">row.names</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>,<span class="pl-v">col.names</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">FALSE</span>)
  }
}

pml_write_files(predict(<span class="pl-smi">ModelRandomForest</span>, <span class="pl-smi">TestingData</span>))
</pre></div>
</article>
  </div>
